trans-unit.source: Allows modification of the comment right after it is prepared for the database.
Allows modification of the comment right before it is inserted via wp_insert_comment(). Returning a WP_Error value from the filter will shortcircuit insertion and allow skipping further processing.
Allows modification of the comment right before it is returned.
Allows modification of the link query arguments before querying.
Allows modification of the post type data right before it is returned.
Allows modification of the response before returning.
Allows modification of the response data after inserting embedded data (if any) and before echoing the response data.
Allows modification of the returned link query results.
Allows modification of the revision right before it is returned.
Allows modification of the status data right before it is returned.
Allows modification of the taxonomy data right before it is returned.
Allows modification of the term data right before it is returned.
Allows overriding the list of months displayed in the media library.
Allows plugins to perform additional validation after a request is initialized and matched to a registered route, but before it is executed.
Allows plugins to perform any needed cleanup, for example, to undo changes made during the ‘rest_request_before_callbacks’ filter.
Allows plugins to queue scripts for the embed iframe end using wp_enqueue_script(). Runs first in oembed_head().
Allows plugins to queue scripts for the front end using wp_enqueue_script(). Runs first in wp_head() where all is_home(), is_page(), etc. functions are available.
Allows preventing auth cookies from actually being sent to the client.
Allows replacement of the editor.
Allows showing or hiding the “Create Audio Playlist” button in the media library.
Allows showing or hiding the “Create Video Playlist” button in the media library.
Allows the Customizer to update a widget using its form, but return the new instance info via Ajax instead of saving it to the options table.
Allows the content to be overridden without having to rewrite the wrapper in $this::render().
Allows the erasure response to be consumed by destinations in addition to Ajax.
Allows the export response to be consumed by destinations in addition to Ajax.
Allows the transport to be easily replaced with long-polling.
Allows theme developers to link a custom stylesheet file to the TinyMCE visual editor. The function tests for the existence of the relative path(s) given as the
Allows to add filters to modify the way a cropped image is saved.
Allows to change and allow external requests for the HTTP request.
Allows values posted back from JS to be rejected if any tampering of the data has occurred.

Allows various options to be set as default values, and merges both the options and URL properties together. A base URL can be set for all requests, with all subrequests resolved from this. Base options can be set (including a shared cookie jar), then overridden for individual requests.
Also allows for the CUSTOM_USER_TABLE and CUSTOM_USER_META_TABLE to override the WordPress users and usermeta tables that would otherwise be determined by the prefix.
Also discards invalid term objects.
Also ensures the post is no longer sticky.
Also forces $_REQUEST to be $_GET + $_POST. If $_SERVER, $_COOKIE, or $_ENV are needed, use those superglobals directly.
Also note that using a string containing a comma separated list will not work here. If you’re passing a variable, make sure it’s a proper array of integer values:
Also note that you cannot set the amount of words and not set the html encoding. If that is the case, then the html encoding will default to 2, which will strip all HTML tags.
Also removes header_image_data.
Also removes any instance of the \0 string.
Also removes custom logo theme mods.

Also uses the function get_post_custom() to get the post’s ‘enclosure’ metadata field and parses the value to display the enclosure(s). The enclosure(s) consist of enclosure HTML tag(s) with a URI and other attributes.

Also uses the function get_post_custom() to get the post’s ‘enclosure’ metadata field and parses the value to display the enclosure(s). The enclosure(s) consist of link HTML tag(s) with a URI and other attributes.
Also, it can optionally contain:
Alter remote path before getting stream data
Alter remote socket information before opening socket connection
Alternative to filter_var( $var, FILTER_VALIDATE_BOOLEAN ).
Alters Main Loop
Alters the list of values in the database to match the list of provided values.
Although

Although height and width are not required parameters, their default values (0) will lead to unwanted behavior, so bear in mind that you should always define them. As mentioned before, use a value of 9999 to define the other dimension as the one to be considered when image resize is executed.
Although you can pass the number of
Always tries to restore widget assignments from previous data, not just if sidebars needed mapping.

Always true if user expressly chooses the option in Appearance > Header. Also true if theme has multiple header images registered, no specific header image is chosen, and theme turns on random headers with add_theme_support().
Always use when escaping HTML attributes (especially form values) such as
Always writes to the file if it exists and is writable to ensure that we blank out old rules.
Amazon
Amount of bookmarks to display. Accepts 1+ or -1 for all. Default -1.
An Underscore (JS) template for rendering this panel’s container.
An Underscore (JS) template for rendering this section.
An Underscore (JS) template for this control’s content (but not its container).
An Underscore (JS) template for this panel’s content (but not its container).
An alias of wp_create_user().
An array containing ‘headers’, ‘body’, ‘response’, ‘cookies’, and ‘filename’ elements
An array containing parent page IDs not to query child pages from.
An array containing parent page IDs to query child pages from.
An array is returned containing the term_id and term_taxonomy_id.
An array of author IDs not to query from.
An array of author IDs to query from.
An array of category IDs (AND in).
An array of category IDs (NOT in).
An array of category IDs (OR in, no children).
An array of counts for available plugin, theme, and WordPress updates.
An array of cron request arguments.
An array of extra strings that will be output within a <supplemental> element as CDATA. Default empty array.
An array of group items.

An array of information about the individual link to a page. $type string $label Label to use for the link. $type string $url URL, relative to network_admin_url() to use for the link. $type string $cap Capability required to see the link. }

An array of labels for this post type. If not set, post labels are inherited for non-hierarchical types and page labels for hierarchical ones. See get_post_type_labels() for a full list of supported labels.

An array of labels for this taxonomy. By default, Tag labels are used for non-hierarchical taxonomies, and Category labels are used for hierarchical taxonomies. See accepted values in get_taxonomy_labels().
An array of logins to exclude. Users matching one of these logins will not be included in results.
An array of logins to include. Users matching one of these logins will be included in results.
An array of multi-widget arguments.
An array of name-value pairs for the item.
An array of nicenames to exclude. Users matching one of these nicenames will not be included in results.
An array of nicenames to include. Users matching one of these nicenames will be included in results.
An array of post IDs not to retrieve. Default empty array.
An array of post IDs not to retrieve. Note: a string of comma- separated IDs will NOT work.
An array of post IDs to retrieve, sticky posts will be included
An array of post IDs to retrieve, sticky posts will be included. Is an alias of $post__in in WP_Query. Default empty array.
An array of post slugs that results must match.
An array of query args to add. Default false.
An array of role names to exclude. Users matching one or more of these roles will not be included in results.
An array of role names to exclude. Users matching one or more of these roles will not be included in results. Default empty array.
An array of role names. Matched users must have at least one of these roles.
An array of role names. Matched users must have at least one of these roles. Default empty array.
An array of tag ids (AND in).
An array of tag ids (NOT in).
An array of tag ids (OR in).
An array of tag slugs (AND in).
An array of tag slugs (OR in). unless 'ignore_sticky_posts' is true. Note: a string of comma-separated IDs will NOT work.
An array of taxonomy identifiers that will be registered for the post type. Taxonomies can be registered later with register_taxonomy() or register_taxonomy_for_object_type().
An array of user IDs to exclude.
An array of user IDs to include.
An array of widget display arguments.
An array or a comma-separated list of role names that users must match to be included in results. Note that this is an inclusive list: users must match *each* role.
An array representing all the modules we wish to test for.
An associative array containing the data to be displayed.
An associative array containing the dissected $query: an array of the query variables and their respective values.
An associative array of WP_Date_Query arguments. See WP_Date_Query::__construct().
An associative array of WP_Meta_Query arguments. See WP_Meta_Query.
An associative array of WP_Tax_Query arguments. See WP_Tax_Query->queries.
An associative array of multi-widget arguments.

An auto-generated excerpt will also have all shortcodes and tags removed. It is trimmed down to a word-boundary and the default length is 55 words. For languages in which words are (or can be) described with single characters (ie. East-Asian languages) the word-boundary is actually the character.
An example can be as seen below.

An example of the ‘base’ argument is "http://example.com/all_posts.php%_%" and the ‘%_%’ is required. The ‘%_%’ will be replaced by the contents of in the ‘format’ argument. An example for the ‘format’ argument is "?page=%#%" and the ‘%#%’ is also required. The ‘%#%’ will be replaced with the page number.
An example of this is:

An existing alias is compatible if (a) it is a sibling of $clause (ie, it’s under the scope of the same relation), and (b) the combination of operator and relation between the clauses allows for a shared table join. In the case of WP_Meta_Query, this only applies to ‘IN’ clauses that are connected by the relation ‘OR’.

An existing alias is compatible if (a) it is a sibling of $clause (ie, it’s under the scope of the same relation), and (b) the combination of operator and relation between the clauses allows for a shared table join. In the case of WP_Tax_Query, this only applies to ‘IN’ clauses that are connected by the relation ‘OR’.
An internal method that sets all the necessary pagination arguments
Anchor text to display in the next comments link. Default 'Newer comments'.
Anchor text to display in the next post link. Default '%title'.
Anchor text to display in the next posts link. Default 'Newer posts'.
Anchor text to display in the previous comments link. Default 'Older comments'.
Anchor text to display in the previous post link. Default '%title'.
Anchor text to display in the previous posts link. Default 'Older posts'.
And your function would be:
Animoto
Announce when a specific setting’s unsanitized post value has been set.
Announce when any setting’s unsanitized post value has been set.

Any [ or ] characters remaining inside elements will be HTML encoded to prevent interference with shortcodes that are outside the elements. Assumes $content processed by KSES already. Users with unfiltered_html capability may get unexpected output if angle braces are nested in tags.
Any column, or columns, to sort the playlist. If $ids are passed, this defaults to the order of the $ids array ('post__in'). Otherwise default is 'menu_order ID'.

Any created menu items will have their assigned post IDs exported to the client via the ‘customize_save_response’ filter. Likewise, any errors will be exported to the client via the customize_save_response() filter.

Any created menus will have their assigned term IDs exported to the client via the ‘customize_save_response’ filter. Likewise, any errors will be exported to the client via the customize_save_response() filter.
Any email headers, defaults to no headers.
Any email headers. Default empty.
Any programmatically-set post values via WP_Customize_Manager::set_post_value().
Any scalar values will be returned as strings. You may coerce the return type of a given option by registering an ‘option_$option’ filter callback.
Any supplied $args override class property defaults.
Any value in the $after parameter that isn’t ‘bottom’ will result in the rule being placed at the top of the rewrite rules.
Append result of internal request to REST API for purpose of preloading data to be attached to a page.
Append the Widgets menu to the themes main menu.
Appends ‘(Draft)’ to draft page titles in the privacy page dropdown so that unpublished content is obvious.
Appends a header value for the given header.
Appends a trailing slash.
Appends data to an XML response based on given arguments.
Applicable if the request is a category, author, permalink or Page. Holds information on the requested category, author, post or Page.
Applied to embedded responses.
Applies only during initial editor instantiation, or when set_quality() is run manually without the $quality argument.
Apply [embed] Ajax handlers to a string.
Argument Name
Arguments may be passed as individual arguments to the method, or as a single array containing all arguments. A combination of the two is not supported.
Arguments prefixed with an _underscore shouldn’t be used by plugins and themes.
Array containing each separate argument to pass to the hook's callback function.
Array format field IDs are now accepted.
Array format field names are now accepted.

Array keys for sections added by core are all prefixed with wp-, plugins and themes should use their own slug as a prefix, both for consistency as well as avoiding key collisions. Note that the array keys are used as labels for the copied data.
Array of IDs or email addresses of users whose unapproved comments will be returned by the query regardless of $status.
Array of IDs or email addresses whose unapproved comments will be included in results.
Array of author IDs *not* to retrieve comments for.
Array of author IDs to exclude comments for.
Array of author IDs to include comments for.
Array of author IDs to retrieve comments for.
Array of capabilities for this post type. $capability_type is used as a base to construct capabilities by default. See get_post_type_capabilities().
Array of capabilities for this taxonomy.
Array of category IDs to mark as checked. Default false.
Array of category IDs to receive the "popular-category" class. Default false.
Array of category IDs. Defaults to value of the 'default_category' option.
Array of column names to be searched. Accepts 'ID', 'login', 'nicename', 'email', 'url'.
Array of column names to be searched. Accepts 'domain' and 'path'.
Array of column names to be searched. Accepts 'domain' and 'path'. Default empty array.
Array of comment IDs to exclude.
Array of comment IDs to include.
Array of domains to exclude affiliated networks for.
Array of domains to exclude affiliated sites for.
Array of domains to include affiliated networks for.
Array of domains to include affiliated sites for.
Array of feed enclosure data to add to post meta.
Array of fields which should or should not be returned.
Array of height, width values, and whether to crop.
Array of language IDs to exclude affiliated sites for.
Array of language IDs to include affiliated sites for.
Array of meta key/value pairs to add to the post.
Array of network IDs to exclude affiliated sites for.
Array of network IDs to exclude.
Array of network IDs to include affiliated sites for.
Array of network IDs to include.
Array of page IDs to exclude.
Array of page IDs to include. Cannot be used with $child_of, $parent, $exclude, $meta_key, $meta_value, or $hierarchical.
Array of parent IDs of comments *not* to retrieve children for.
Array of parent IDs of comments to retrieve children for.
Array of paths to exclude affiliated networks for.
Array of paths to exclude affiliated sites for.
Array of paths to include affiliated networks for.
Array of paths to include affiliated sites for.
Array of personal data exporters.
Array of post IDs to exclude affiliated comments for.
Array of post IDs to include affiliated comments for.
Array of post meta values keyed by their post meta key. Default empty.
Array of site IDs to exclude.
Array of site IDs to include.
Array of tag names, slugs, or IDs. Default empty.
Array of taxonomy terms keyed by their taxonomy name. Default empty.
Array of the basename paths of the plugins' main files.
Array of translations update data.
Array or comma-separated list of excluded term IDs.
Array or comma-separated list of user IDs to exclude.
Array or comma-separated list of user IDs to include.
Array or comma/space-separated list of author IDs to exclude.
Array or comma/space-separated list of author IDs to include.
Array or comma/space-separated string of term IDs to exclude, along with their descendants. See get_terms().
Array or comma/space-separated string of term IDs to exclude. If $hierarchical is true, descendants of $exclude terms will also be excluded; see $exclude_tree. See get_terms().
Array or comma/space-separated string of term ids to exclude along with all of their descendant terms. If $include is non-empty, $exclude_tree is ignored. Default empty array.
Array or comma/space-separated string of term ids to exclude. If $include is non-empty, $exclude is ignored. Default empty array.
Array or comma/space-separated string of term ids to include. Default empty array.
Array or string of additional classes to add to the <img> element.
Array or string of headers to send with the request.
Array support was added to the $query parameter.

Array with image url, width, height, and whether is intermediate size, in that order is returned on success is returned. $is_intermediate is true if $url is a resized image, false if it is the original.
ArrayAccess
As a shorthand, the desired HTTP response code may be passed as an integer to the $title parameter (the default title would apply) or the $args parameter.

As of WordPress 3.5.0, XML-RPC is enabled by default. It can be disabled via the ‘xmlrpc_enabled’ filter found in wp_xmlrpc_server::login().
As per RFC 6265, cookies are separated by ‘; ‘
As per RFC6266:
As such, you don’t need to worry about that.
As the excerpt should be a small string of text relevant to the full post content, this function renders the blocks that are most likely to contain such text.
Assign a format to a post
Assign an endpoint mask. Default EP_NONE.
Assign default styles to $styles object.
Assign role a capability.
Associative array mapping a partial ID its corresponding array of contents for the containers requested.
Associative array of final matches. Index == row number of $final, value == corresponding row number of that same line in $orig or 'x' if there is no corresponding row (indicating it is a new line).
Associative array of interleaved rows of $final with blanks to keep matches aligned with side-by-side diff of $orig. A value >= 0 corresponds to index of $final. Value < 0 indicates a blank row.
Associative array of interleaved rows of $orig with blanks to keep matches aligned with side-by-side diff of $final. A value >= 0 corresponds to index of $orig. Value < 0 indicates a blank row.

Associative array of original matches. Index == row number of $orig, value == corresponding row number of that same line in $final or 'x' if there is no corresponding row (indicating it is a deleted line).
Associative array with taxonomy names as keys and arrays of term IDs as values.
Associative array with taxonomy names as keys and arrays of term names as values.
Assumes first char of $text is tag opening and last char is tag closing. Assumes second char of $text is optionally ‘/’ to indicate closing as in .
Assumes that WP_Filesystem() has already been called and set up.
Assumes that WP_Filesystem() has already been called and set up. Does not extract a root-level __MACOSX directory, if present.
Assumes that WP_Filesystem() has already been called and setup.
Assumes that on Windows systems, Stripping off the Drive letter is OK Sanitizes \ to / in Windows filepaths.

Assumes there are neither duplicated nor orphaned capabilities meta_values. Assumes role names are unique phrases. Same assumption made by WP_User_Query::prepare_query() Using $strategy = ‘time’ this is CPU-intensive and should handle around 10^7 users. Using $strategy = ‘memory’ this is memory-intensive and should handle around 10^5 users, but see WP Bug #12257.
Asynchronously upgrades language packs after other upgrades have been made.
At 2.3 this combination will return posts belong to both Category 1 AND 3, showing just two (2) posts, in descending order by the title:
At minimum, either a height or width must be provided. If one of the two is set to null, the resize will maintain aspect ratio according to the provided dimension.
At the time of this action, the only recourse is to redirect somewhere and exit. If you want to declare a particular network, do so earlier.
At the time of this action, the only recourse is to redirect somewhere and exit. If you want to declare a particular site, do so earlier.

Attached to the ‘http_request_host_is_external’ filter.
Attached to the ‘rest_api_init’ action to make testing and disabling these filters easier.
Attached to the ‘wp’ action.
Attached to the ‘wp_head’ action.
Attached to the ‘wp_update_term_parent’ filter.
Attachment post ID. Used for 'attachment' post_type.

Attachments may also be made the child of a post, so if that is an accurate statement (which needs to be verified), it would then be possible to get all of the attachments for a post. Attachments have since changed since version 2.5, so this is most likely inaccurate, but serves generally as an example of what is possible.
Attempt an early load of translations.
Attempt to determine the real file type of a file.
Attempt to edit a file for a theme or plugin.

Attempting to filter by an invalid date value (eg month=13) will generate SQL that will return no results. In these cases, a _doing_it_wrong() error notice is also thrown. See WP_Date_Query::validate_date_values().
Attempts activation of plugin in a “sandbox” and redirects on success.

Attempts to convert a URL into embed HTML. Starts by checking the URL against the regex of the registered embed handlers. If none of the regex matches and it’s enabled, then the URL will be given to the WP_oEmbed class.
Attempts to detect the route to access a single item.
Attempts to discover link tags at the given URL for an oEmbed provider.
Attempts to download the package (if it is not a local file), unpack it, and install it in the destination folder.
Attempts to fetch the embed HTML for a provided URL using oEmbed.
Attempts to find the current slug from the past slugs.
Attempts to guess the correct URL based on query vars
Attempts to increase the PHP memory limit to 256M before uncompressing. However, the most memory required shouldn’t be much larger than the archive itself.
Attempts to raise the PHP memory limit for memory intensive processes.
Attempts to retrieve from the cache first based on MD5 hash of arguments. If that fails, then the query will be built from the arguments and executed. The results will be stored to the cache.
Attempts to unzip an archive using the PclZip library.
Attempts to unzip an archive using the ZipArchive class.
Attributes and other data can be accessed via methods.
Audio embed handler callback.
Authenticate a user, confirming the login credentials are valid.
Authenticate a user, confirming the username and password are valid.
Authenticate the user using the WordPress auth cookie.
Authenticates a user using the email and password.
Authenticates and logs a user in with ‘remember’ capability.

Authentication methods should check first if they’re being used, as multiple authentication methods can be enabled on a site (cookies, HTTP basic auth, OAuth). If the authentication method hooked in is not actually being attempted, null should be returned to indicate another authentication method should check instead. Similarly, callbacks should ensure the value is null before checking for errors.
Author ID, or comma-separated list of IDs.
Author Parameters
Author to export content for. Only used when $content is 'post', 'page', or 'attachment'. Accepts false (all) or a specific author ID. Default false (all).
Author’s own copyright
Author's name.
Author's website address (if set).

Author, Author Name, Author URI, and Description did not previously return translated data. We are doing so now as it is safe to do. However, as Name and Title could have been used as the key for get_themes(), both remain untranslated for back compatibility. This means that [‘Name’] is not ideal, and care should be taken to use $theme::display( 'Name' ) to get a properly translated header.

Avoids a collision between a site slug and a permalink slug.

Background updates in WordPress are primarily used for minor releases and security updates. It’s important to either have these working, or be aware that they are intentionally disabled for whatever reason.
Backported from 2.1.3 to 2.0.10.
Backported to 2.0.10 from 2.1.3.
Backported to 2.0.10.

Balances tags if forced to, or if the ‘use_balanceTags’ option is set to true.
Balances tags of string using a modified stack.
Base WordPress Filesystem class which Filesystem implementations extend.
Base class for displaying a list of items in an ajaxified HTML table.
Base image editor class from which implementations extend
Base of the paginated url.
Based off the HTTP http_encoding_dechunk function.
Based on touch_time().
Based on Requests_IRI::replace_invalid_with_pct_encoding()
Based on wp_kses_hair() but does not return a multi-dimensional array.
Based on wp_kses_split2() and wp_kses_attr().
Based on Mozilla’s parsing code in Firefox and related projects, which is an intentional deviation from RFC 2109 and RFC 2616. RFC 6265 specifies some of this handling, but not in a thorough manner.
Based on WP_Editor::wp_link_query().
Based on a supplied width/height example, return the biggest possible dimensions based on the max width/height.
Based on concepts from SimplePie_File, RequestCore and WP_Http.
Basic Authentication provider
Basic Usage

Be aware of the queries you are changing when using the pre_get_posts action. Make use of conditional tags to target the right query. For example, its recommended to use the the is_admin() conditional to not change queries in the admin screens. With the $query->is_main_query() conditional from the query object you can target the main query of a page request. The main query is used by the primary post loop that displays the main content for a post, page or archive. Without these conditionals you could unintentionally be changing the query for custom loops in sidebars, footers, or elsewhere.
Be careful not to confuse the two query conditionals:
Be sure to flush the rewrite rules – see flush_rewrite_rules() – when your plugin gets activated and deactivated.

Because wp_get_sidebars_widgets() gets called early at ‘init’ (via wp_convert_widget_settings()) and can set global variable $_wp_sidebars_widgets to the value of get_option( 'sidebars_widgets' ) before the Customizer preview filter is added, it has to be reset after the filter has been added.
Becomes:
Before Maintenance Mode is disabled.
Before Maintenance Mode is enabled.
Before WordPress begins copying over the necessary files.
Before WordPress begins the core upgrade process.
Before the database is upgraded.
Begins keeping track of changes to widget options, caching new values.
Begins keeping track of the current sidebar being rendered.
Besides the common blog_id (unused), username, and password arguments, it takes a comment_id integer and a content_struct array as last argument.
Besides the common blog_id (unused), username, and password arguments, it takes a filter array as last argument.
Blip
Block attributes mapping, property name to schema.
Block requests through the proxy.
Blog ID (unused).
Blog title.
Body to send with the request. Default null.

Booleans dictating what type of request this is. For example, the first three represent ‘is it a permalink?’, ‘is it a Page?’, ‘is it any type of archive page?’, respectively. See also Conditional Tags.
Bootstraps the Customize experience on the server-side.
Both $name and $value can contain only ASCII letters, numbers and underscores.
Both get_comment_author_url() and get_comment_author() rely on get_comment(), which falls back to the global comment variable if the $comment_ID argument is empty.
Both attributes are required in the sense that both parameters must have a value, but are optional in that if you set them to false or null, then they will not be added to the returned string.

Both single events and recurring events are passed through this filter; single events have $event->schedule as false, whereas recurring events have this set to a recurrence from wp_get_schedules(). Recurring events also have the integer recurrence interval set as $event->interval.
Bound callbacks can accept from none to the total number of arguments passed as parameters

Bump up the request timeout for http requests

By contrast, when changeset branching is allowed, then the model is like users going to "add new" for a page and each user makes changes independently of each other since they are all operating on their own separate pages, each getting their own separate initial auto-drafts and then once initially saved, autosave revisions on top of that user’s specific post.

By default (if this filter does not return an array), a query will be run to determine the months that have media items. This query can be expensive for large media libraries, so it may be desirable for sites to override this behavior.
By default a revision is saved only if one of the revisioned fields has changed. This filter allows for additional checks to determine if there were changes.
By default a revision is saved only if one of the revisioned fields has changed. This filter can override that so a revision is saved even if nothing has changed.
By default a subset of the_content filters are applied, including wpautop and wptexturize.
By default database errors are not shown.
By default database errors are suppressed, with a simple call to this function they can be enabled.
By default editing of network is restricted to the Network Admin for that $network_id. This function allows for this to be overridden.

By default in core, when changeset branching is not allowed, changesets will operate linearly in that only one saved changeset will exist at a time (with a ‘draft’ or ‘future’ status). This makes the Customizer operate in a way that is similar to going to "edit" to one existing post: all users will be making changes to the same post, and autosave revisions will be made for that post.
By default it supports the ‘src’ and ‘href’ attributes. However this can be changed via the 3rd param.

By default messages will show immediately after the submission that generated the error. Additional calls to settings_errors() can be used to show errors even when the settings page is first accessed.
By default the path will go through the ‘get_attached_file’ filter, but passing a true to the $unfiltered argument of get_attached_file() will return the file path unfiltered.
By default the privacy options form displays a single checkbox to ‘discourage’ search engines from indexing the site. Hooking to this action serves a dual purpose:
By default this column is hidden unless something is hooked to the action.

By default this displays the default sidebar or ‘sidebar-1’. If your theme specifies the ‘id’ or ‘name’ parameter for its registered sidebars you can pass an id or name as the $index parameter. Otherwise, you can pass in a numerical index to display the sidebar at that index.
By default, wp_list_categories() displays:
By default, WordPress bundles many popular scripts commonly used by web developers besides the scripts used by core itself. Below is an (incomplete) list of the handles and paths of these scripts.
By default, WordPress installation includes many popular scripts commonly used by web developers besides the scripts used by WordPress itself. Some of them are listed in the table below.

By default, WordPress will show password protected posts with a title of "Protected: %s", as the REST API communicates the protected status of a post in a machine readable format, we remove the "Protected: " prefix.

By default, WordPress will show password protected posts with a title of "Protected: %s". As the REST API communicates the protected status of a post in a machine readable format, we remove the "Protected: " prefix.
By default, administrators are notified when the update offer received from WordPress.org sets a particular flag. This allows some discretion in if and when to notify.
By default, an empty string. A user object if provided.
By default, an infinite number of revisions are kept.
By default, comment authors aren’t notified of their comments on their own posts. This filter allows you to override that.
By default, only post authors are notified of comments. This filter allows others to be added.
By default, seven keys are accepted as part of the capabilities array:

By default, spaces include new lines, tabs, nbsp entities, and the UTF-8 nbsp. This is designed to replace the PCRE \s sequence. In ticket #22692, that sequence was found to be unreliable due to random inclusion of the A0 byte.

By default, the "Create Audio Playlist" button will always be shown in the media library. If this filter returns null, a query will be run to determine whether the media library contains any audio items. This was the default behavior prior to version 4.8.0, but this query is expensive for large media libraries.

By default, the "Create Video Playlist" button will always be shown in the media library. If this filter returns null, a query will be run to determine whether the media library contains any video items. This was the default behavior prior to version 4.8.0, but this query is expensive for large media libraries.
By default, the caption is 10 pixels greater than the width of the image, to prevent post content from running up against a floated image.
By default, the comment will be moved to the trash instead of deleted. See wp_delete_comment() for more information on this behavior.
By default, the comments will use the default settings for whether the comments are allowed. You can close them manually or keep them open by setting the value for the ‘comment_status’ key.
By default, the lifetime is 3 days. Once the file reaches that age, it will automatically be deleted by a cron job.

By default, the page title will display the separator before the page title, so that the blog title will be before the page title. This is not good for title display, since the blog title shows up on most tabs and not what is important, which is the page that the user is looking at.

By default, the schema of settings will throw an error if a value is set to null as it’s not a valid value for something like "type => string". We provide a wrapper sanitizer to whitelist the use of null.
By default, these values default to ‘center’ when using hard crop mode.
By default, updates all the tables to use the latest defined schema, but can also be used to update a specific set of tables in wp_get_db_schema().
By including the context in the pot file, translators can translate the two strings differently.
C
CONFIRM_URL### The link to click on to confirm the account action.

CSS text size unit to use with the $smallest and $largest values. Accepts any valid CSS text size unit. Default 'pt'.
CSSLint rule overrides.
CURIEs allow a shortened version of URI relations. This allows a more usable form for custom relations than using the full URI. These work similarly to how XML namespaces work.

Cache entries keyed by the theme and the type of data.

Call hooks for when a comment status transition occurs.
Call like the_shortlink( __( ‘Shortlinkage FTW’ ) )
Call major cache updating functions for list of Post objects.
Call the ‘all’ hook, which will process the functions hooked into it.

Call this in template files after admin.php is loaded and before admin-header.php is loaded to add a sidebar to the contextual help.
Call this in template files after admin.php is loaded and before admin-header.php is loaded to add screen options.
Call this on the load-$pagenow hook for the relevant screen.

Callable eraser that accepts an email address and a page and returns an array with boolean values for whether items were removed or retained and any messages from the eraser, as well as if additional pages are available.
Callable exporter function that accepts an email address and a page and returns an array of name => value pairs of personal data.
Callback for transport.internal.parse_response
Callback for handling a menu item when its original object is deleted.
Callback for rendering the custom logo, used in the custom_logo partial.

Callback for the embed API endpoint.

Callback function for Activity widget.
Callback function for ob_start() to capture all links in the theme.

Callback function for sanitizing taxonomy data saved from a meta box. If no callback is defined, an appropriate one is determined based on the value of $meta_box_cb.
Callback function for usort() to naturally sort themes by name.
Callback function for usort() to naturally sort themes by translated name.
Callback function to filter multidimensional theme mods and options.

Callback function to use. Default null.

Callback to add a base url to relative links in passed content.

Callback to convert URL match to HTML A element.
Callback to fire if the menu doesn't exist. Default empty.
Callback to sort the list by specific fields.
Callback to validate a theme once it is loaded
Callback used to determine the tag count scaling value. Default default_topic_count_scale().
Callback used to generate nooped plural text for tag counts based on the count. Default null.
Callback used to render blocks of this block type.

Called by admin-header.php and ‘wp_head’ hook. Since it is called by wp_head on every page load, the function does not instantiate the WP_Scripts object unless script names are explicitly passed. Makes use of already-instantiated $wp_scripts global if present. Use provided ‘wp_print_scripts’ hook to register/enqueue new scripts.
Called by the public WP_Date_Query::get_sql(), this method is abstracted out to maintain parity with the other Query classes.
Called by the public WP_Meta_Query::get_sql(), this method is abstracted out to maintain parity with the other Query classes.
Called by the public WP_Tax_Query::get_sql(), this method is abstracted out to maintain parity with the other Query classes.
Called from dynamic_sidebar().
Called upon object destruction, which should be when PHP ends.
Called when WordPress is generating the table scheme.
Calls ‘widgets_init’ action after all of the WordPress widgets have been registered.
Calls WP_Rewrite::wp_rewrite_rules() after removing the ‘rewrite_rules’ option. If the function named ‘save_mod_rewrite_rules’ exists, it will be called.
Calls wp_write_post() and handles the errors.
Calls admin_print_footer_scripts and admin_print_scripts hooks to allow custom scripts from plugins.
Calls admin_print_scripts-widgets.php and admin_print_scripts hooks to allow custom scripts from plugins.
Calls admin_print_styles-widgets.php and admin_print_styles hooks to allow custom styles from plugins.
Calls all core functions to check for updates.

Calls hooks for comment status transitions. If the new comment status is not the same as the previous comment status, then two hooks will be ran, the first is ‘transition_comment_status’ with new status, old status, and comment data. The next action called is comment_$old_status_to_$new_status’. It has the comment data.
Calls the ‘loop_end’ action when the loop is complete.
Calls the callback functions added to a filter hook.
Calls the uninstall hook, if it is available.
Calls widget control callback.
Can be disabled with remove_action( ‘admin_enqueue_scripts’, ‘wp_auth_check_load’ );
Can be either next post link or previous.
Can be used in place of add_post_meta().
Can be used to attach further information to a session.
Can be used within the WordPress loop or outside of it, with any post type.
Can be used within the WordPress loop or outside of it. Can be used with pages, posts, attachments, and revisions.
Can be useful for plugins when deactivating to clean up the cron queue.
Can either be next or previous post relational link.
Can either be next or previous post.
Can either be start or end post relational link.
Can not be used to unregister built-in post types.
Can not be used to unregister built-in taxonomies.
Can only be used to remove permastructs that were added using add_permastruct(). Built-in permastructs cannot be removed.

Care should be taken through prefixing or other means to ensure that the shortcode tag being added is unique and will not conflict with other, already-added shortcode tags. In the event of a duplicated tag, the tag loaded last will take precedence.
Care should be taken to protect the email address and assure that email harvesters do not capture your commenter’s email address.

Care should be taken to protect the email address and assure that email harvesters do not capture your commenter’s email address. Most assume that their email address will not appear in raw form on the site. Doing so will enable anyone, including those that people don’t want to get the email address and use it for their own means good and bad.
Case-insensitive dictionary, suitable for HTTP headers

Catches YouTube iframe embed URLs that are not parsable by oEmbed but can be translated into a URL that is.
Categories
Categories need to be passed as an array of integers that match the category IDs in the database. This is the case even where only one category is assigned to the post.

Category (slug) to export content for. Used only when $content is 'post'. If set, only post content assigned to $category will be exported. Accepts false or a specific category slug. Default is false (all categories).
Category ID or comma-separated list of IDs (this or any children).
Category ID or comma-separated list of IDs (this or any children). Is an alias of $cat in WP_Query. Default 0.
Category ID. A non-zero value updates an existing category. Default 0.
Category Parameters
Category depth. Used for tab indentation. Default 0.
Category description. Default empty.
Category name. Default empty.
Category nice (display) name. Default empty.
Category parent ID. Default empty.
Category to retrieve links for by name.

Certain Servers will return deflated data with headers which PHP’s gzinflate() function cannot handle out of the box. The following function has been created from various snippets on the gzinflate() PHP documentation.
Change the allowed HTTP origin result.
Change the current SQL mode, and ensure its WordPress compatibility.
Change the origin of an HTTP request.
Change the origin types allowed for HTTP requests.
Changed the function signature so that the $args array can be provided as the first parameter. Introduced 'meta_key' and 'meta_value' parameters. Introduced the ability to order results by metadata.
Changelog
Changes 302 redirects from POST to GET to match browser handling. Per RFC 7231, user agents can deviate from the strict reading of the specification for compatibility purposes.
Changes a boolean-like value into the proper boolean value.
Changes current directory.
Changes filesystem permissions.
Changes the current user by ID or name.
Changes the file group.
Changes the owner of a file or directory.
Changes the site’s locale to the given one.

Changeset UUID, the post_name for the customize_changeset post containing the customized state. Defaults to null resulting in a UUID to be immediately generated. If false is provided, then then the changeset UUID will be determined during after_setup_theme: when the customize_changeset_branching filter returns false, then the default UUID will be that of the most recent customize_changeset post that has a status other than 'auto-draft', 'publish', or 'trash'. Otherwise, if changeset branching is enabled, then a random UUID will be used.
Changeset UUID.

Checks if a given request has access to update the current user.
Checks if a meta key is registered.
Checks if a parameter is set.
Checks if a post can be created.
Checks if a post can be deleted.
Checks if a post can be edited.
Checks if a post can be read.
Checks if a request has access to create a term.
Checks if a request has access to delete the specified term.
Checks if a request has access to read or edit the specified term.
Checks if a request has access to read terms in the specified taxonomy.
Checks if a request has access to update the specified term.
Checks if a sidebar is registered.
Checks if a specific action has been registered for this hook.
Checks if a theme has been changed and runs ‘after_switch_theme’ hook on the next WP load.
Checks if a user is logged in, if not it redirects them to the login page.
Checks if any callbacks have been registered for this hook.
Checks if current locale is RTL.
Checks if current position is valid.
Checks if current user can make a proxy oEmbed request.
Checks if resource is a directory.
Checks if resource is a file.
Checks if the blog is deleted, inactive, archived, or spammed.
Checks if the comment can be read.
Checks if the current post has any of given tags.
Checks if the current post is within any of the given categories.
Checks if the current theme is active.
Checks if the current user belong to a given site.
Checks if the current user has permissions to import new users.
Checks if the current user-settings cookie is updated and stores it. When no cookie exists (different browser used), adds the last saved cookie restoring the settings.
Checks if the given IP is a valid IPv6 address
Checks if the method received at least the minimum number of arguments.
Checks if the post can be read.
Checks if the response is an error, i.e. >= 400 response code.
Checks if the user can access password-protected content.
Checks if the user can access the visual editor and that it’s supported by the user’s browser.
Checks if the user can refresh this partial.
Checks if the user can use this control.
Checks if the user needs to update PHP.
Checks required user capabilities and whether the theme has the feature support required by the panel.
Checks required user capabilities and whether the theme has the feature support required by the section.
Checks status of current blog.
Checks that a JSONP callback is a valid JavaScript callback.
Checks that current theme files ‘index.php’ and ‘style.css’ exists.
Checks that the connection to the database is still up. If not, try to reconnect.
Checks that the given token is present and hasn’t expired.
Checks that the main plugin file exists and is a valid plugin. See validate_file().
Checks that the taxonomy is valid.
Checks that the taxonomy name exists.
Checks the $wp_settings_errors array for any errors declared during the current pageload and returns them.

Checks the ‘upload_path’ option, which should be from the web root folder, and if it isn’t empty it will be used. If it is empty, then the path will be ‘WP_CONTENT_DIR/uploads’. If the ‘UPLOADS’ constant is defined, then it will override the ‘upload_path’ option and ‘WP_CONTENT_DIR/uploads’ path.

Checks the HTML for the rel="pingback" link and x-pingback headers. It does a check for the x-pingback headers first and returns that, if available. The check for the rel="pingback" has more overhead than just the header.
Checks the age against $this->reference_time to determine if the cookie is expired.
Checks the authentication headers if supplied.
Checks the current user’s permissions
Checks the data provided by the user during blog signup. Verifies the validity and uniqueness of blog paths and domains.
Checks the given subset of the term hierarchy for hierarchy loops.
Checks the logged-in cookie if the previous auth cookie could not be validated and parsed.
Checks the plaintext password against the encrypted Password.
Checks the post excerpt and prepare it for single post output.
Checks the post_date_gmt or modified_gmt and prepare any post or modified date for single post output.
Checks the version of the installed MySQL binary.
Checks to make sure that the embeds library hasn’t already been loaded. If it hasn’t, then it will load the embeds library.
Checks to make sure that the taxonomy is an object first. Then Gets the object, and finally returns the hierarchical value in the object.
Checks to make sure that the widgets library hasn’t already been loaded. If it hasn’t, then it will load the widgets library and run an action hook.
Checks to see if a string is utf8 encoded.
Checks to see if all of the feed url in $check_urls are cached.
Checks to see if current environment supports GD.
Checks to see if current environment supports Imagick.
Checks to see if current environment supports the editor chosen.
Checks to see if editor supports the mime-type specified.
Checks to see if more than one author has published posts.
Checks to see if the current clause has any time-related keys. If so, it’s first-order.
Checks to see if the user has deleted the tinymce files to slim down their WordPress installation.
Checks user capabilities and theme supports, and then saves the value of the setting.
Checks whether a given post status should be visible.
Checks whether a given request has permission to read post statuses.
Checks whether a given request has permission to read taxonomies.
Checks whether a given request has permission to read types.
Checks whether a site is initialized.
Checks whether a site name is already taken.
Checks whether a username is valid.
Checks whether comment flooding is occurring.
Checks whether current request is a JSON request, or is expecting a JSON response.
Checks whether current request is a JSONP request, or is expecting a JSONP response.
Checks whether current request is an XML request, or is expecting an XML response.
Checks whether current user can assign all terms sent with the current request.
Checks whether or not the supplied array is a struct or not
Checks whether recovery mode has been initialized.
Checks whether recovery mode is active.
Checks whether the $location is using an allowed host, if it has an absolute path. A plugin can therefore set or remove allowed host(s) to or from the list.
Checks whether the current query has any OR relations.
Checks whether the custom header video is eligible to show on the current page.
Checks whether the fatal error handler is enabled.
Checks whether the given extension a network activated plugin.
Checks whether the recovery mode cookie is set.
Checks whether the request is for rendering partials.
Checks whether the underlying API to store paused extensions is loaded.
Checks whether this request is valid according to its attributes.
Choose a header image, selected from existing uploaded and default headers, or provide an array of uploaded header data (either new, or from media library).
Choose the maximum level the user has.

Class attribute of the select element.
Class for generating SQL clauses that filter a primary query according to date.
Class for looking up a site’s health based on a user’s WordPress environment.
Class for providing debug data based on a users WordPress environment.
Class for testing automatic updates in the WordPress code.
Class name for the widget's HTML container. Default is a shortened version of the output callback name.
Class name that aligns the caption. Default 'alignnone'. Accepts 'alignleft', 'aligncenter', alignright', 'alignnone'.
Class that is applied to the container. Default 'menu-{menu slug}-container'.
Class to use for the element containing the page list. Default 'menu'.
Class to validate and to work with IPv6 addresses
Class used for querying terms.

Class variables for this panel class are available in the data JS object; export custom variables by overriding WP_Customize_Panel::json().

Clean (read: delete) page from cache that matches $id. Will also clean cache associated with ‘all_page_ids’ and ‘get_pages’.

Clean the blog cache
Clean the caches for a taxonomy.
Clean up an array, comma- or space-separated list of IDs.
Clean up an array, comma- or space-separated list of slugs.
Cleaning means delete from the cache of the post. Will call to clean the term object cache associated with the post ID.
Cleaning means delete from the cache. Optionally will clean the term object cache associated with the attachment ID.
Cleans any recovery mode keys that have expired according to the link TTL.
Cleans the necessary caches after specific site data has been updated.
Cleans the site details cache for a site.
Cleans the user cache for a specific user.
Cleans up Genericons example files.
Cleans up an array, comma- or space-separated list of scalar values.
Cleans up export files older than three days old.
Cleans up failed and expired requests before displaying the list table.
Cleanse the field value in the term based on the context.

Clear all shortcodes.
Clear existing update caches for plugins, themes, and core.
Clear out the previewed-applied flag for a multidimensional-aggregated value whenever its post value is updated.

Clear the cached value when this nav menu item is updated.
Clear the destination resource.
Clear the lastcommentmodified cached value when a comment status is changed.
Clear the working resource.
Clears existing translations where this item is going to be installed into.
Clears the Plugins cache used by get_plugins() and by default, the Plugin Update cache.
Clears the Plugins cache used by get_plugins() and by default, the Plugin Update cache.
Clears the authentication cookie, logging the user out. This function is deprecated.
Clears the cache for the theme.
Clears the cache held by get_theme_roots() and WP_Theme.
Clears the cache held by get_theme_roots() and WP_Theme.
Clears the directory where this item is going to be installed into.
Clears the object cache of all data.
Clears the rate limit, allowing a new recovery mode email to be sent immediately.
Clears the recovery mode cookie.
